President of [[Texas A&M University]] }} '''Alvin Roubal Luedecke''' (10 October 1910 – 9 August 1998) was a [[United States Army Air Forces]] general during [[World War II]]. He commanded the [[Armed Forces Special Weapons Project]] after the war. After retiring from the Air Force in 1958, he was General Manager of the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission]], Deputy Director of the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] and President of [[Texas A&M University]]. ==Early life and career== Alvin Roubal Luedecke was born in [[Eldorado, Texas]], on 1 October 1910,{{harvnb|Ancell|Miller|1996|p=417}} the oldest of eight children of John H. Luedecke, a rancher, and his wife Lizzie. He grew up on the family ranch.{{cite news |url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1998-08-13/news/9808120313_1_maj-west-texas-retirement |newspaper=The San Antonio Express-News |date=13 August 1998 |title=Maj. Gen. Alvin Luedecke, Atomic Energy Board Official |accessdate=20 August 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120915015527/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1998-08-13/news/9808120313_1_maj-west-texas-retirement | archivedate = 2012-09-15| deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://old-photos.blogspot.com/2008/04/john-h-luedecke.html |title=Old Picture of the Day |publisher=Blogspot |accessdate=20 August 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121023093957/http://old-photos.blogspot.com/2008/04/john-h-luedecke.html | archivedate = 2012-10-23| deadurl=no}} He earned a [[bachelor of science]] degree in chemical engineering from the [[Texas A&M]] in 1932.{{harvnb|Fogerty|1953}} Luedecke was commissioned as a [[second lieutenant]] in the [[field artillery]] reserve on 28 May 1932, and was posted to [[Camp Bullis, Texas]], on [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]] duty. He became a flying cadet on 21 February 1933. After completing his flight training at the Primary Flying School at [[Randolph Field, Texas]], and the Advanced Flying School Bomber course at [[March Field, California]], and [[Hamilton Field, California]], he received a reserve commission as a second lieutenant in the [[United States Army Air Corps]] on 20 February 1935.{{cite web |url=http://www.af.mil/information/bios/bio.asp?bioID=6247 |title=Major General Alvin R. Luedecke |publisher=United States Air Force |accessdate=20 August 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130802152040/http://www.af.mil/information/bios/bio.asp?bioID=6247 | archivedate = 2013-08-02| deadurl=yes}} Luedecke was posted to the [[11th Bombardment Squadron]] at Hamilton Field. The next year he became group operations and intelligence officer of the [[7th Bombardment Group]] there. On 1 October 1938 he was commissioned as a regular second lieutenant in the Army Air Corps, and was posted to the [[25th Bombardment Squadron]] at [[France Field]] in the [[Panama Canal Zone]]. ==World War II== Luedecke was assistant [[military attaché]] for Air to Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Panama and Nicaragua from 23 January 1940 to 19 August 1942. He then became executive air officer at the field office of the Military Intelligence Services, Quarry Heights in the Panama Canal Zone. There he was promoted to captain on 1 February 1942, [[major]] on 19 November 1942, and [[Lieutenant Colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]] on 5 January 1943. That month he returned to the United States as chief of the Operations Branch, Air Control Group, American Intelligence Command at [[Miami Beach, Florida]]. The next month he became chief of the Latin American Branch, American Intelligence Command. For his service in Central America, he was awarded the Colombian Order of Boyaca. On 12 May 1943 he was appointed deputy commander of the [[39th Bombardment Group]], based at [[Davis-Monthan Field]], Arizona. He became executive officer of the [[16th Bombardment Operations Training Wing]] there on 27 June, with a promotion to [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] on 22 July 1943. In August 1943 he was appointed Chief of the Operations and Training Section of the Army Air Forces in the India-Burma Sector of the [[China-Burma-India Theater]]. On 18 August 1944 he was promoted to [[Brigadier General (United States)|brigadier general]] at the age of 33. He became Deputy Chief of Staff in November 1944. In July 1945 he was made Assistant Chief of Air Staff for Plans, Operations, Training and Intelligence in the [[China Theater]]. For his service in China, he was awarded the Chinese [[Order of the Cloud and Banner]]. He was also given a British [[mention in despatches]] and made a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]]. He was awarded the [[Legion of Merit]] on 8 January 1944, with an [[oak leaf cluster]] on 25 October 1945, the [[Bronze Star Medal]] on 19 November 1945, and the [[Commendation Ribbon]] on 29 May 1946. He was also awarded an honorary [[Legum Doctor]] (LLD) degree by Texas A&M in 1946.{{cite web |url=http://www.aggienetwork.com/building/tribute.aspx?exhibit=0 |title=Tribute Wall |accessdate=30 March 2012 |publisher=The Association of Former Students of Texas A&M University | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121006030731/http://www.aggienetwork.com/building/tribute.aspx?exhibit=0 | archivedate = 2012-10-06| deadurl=no}} ==Cold War== Luedecke returned to the United States in February 1946, and was assigned to the Joint War Plans Committee in Washington, D.C., as the senior Army Air Force member. On 22 October 1947 he became Assistant Director of the Joint Strategic Plans Group. On 14 June 1949 he was posted to the Military Liaison Committee of the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission]] as executive military secretary. On 16 March 1951 he became the Air Force Deputy Chief of the [[Armed Forces Special Weapons Project]]. After the Chief of the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project, Major General [[Herbert B. Loper]], had a heart attack and was forced to retire, Luedecke stepped up to become chief, with the rank of major general.{{sfn|Brahmstedt|2002|p=99}} Starting with [[Operation Crossroads]] in 1946, the practice had been to form a joint task force to plan and conduct each series of nuclear tests in the Pacific. When they became more frequent, the Joint Chiefs created Joint Task Force 7 as a permanent body.{{sfn|Brahmstedt|2002|p=99}} Luedecke assumed command of Joint Task Force 7 on 1 April 1957. On 10 June he was succeeded as Chief of the Armed Forces Special Weapons Project by Rear Admiral [[Edward N. Parker]], but remained commander of Joint Task Force 7. As such, he was responsible for the planning, preparation and conduct of [[Operation Hardtack I]] and [[Operation Hardtack II]].{{sfn|Hewlett|Holl|1989|p=493}} For his services, he was awarded the [[Air Force Distinguished Service Medal]]. ==Later life== Luedecke retired from the Air Force in 1958 to replace [[Kenneth D. Nichols]] as General Manager of the Atomic Energy Commission.{{sfn|Hewlett|Holl|1989|p=493}} In 1964 Luedecke was appointed Deputy Director of the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]. Over the next three years he worked on the unmanned [[Ranger program|Ranger]], [[Mariner program|Mariner]], [[Surveyor Program|Surveyor]] and [[Voyager program|Voyager]] space exploration programs. For his services to NASA, he was awarded the [[NASA Exceptional Service Medal]] in 1968.{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-08-14/news/9808140219_1_texas-engineering-experiment-station-atomic-energy-commission-bronze-star |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=21 August 2011 |date=14 August 1998 |title=A. R. Luedecke | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121006055124/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-08-14/news/9808140219_1_texas-engineering-experiment-station-atomic-energy-commission-bronze-star | archivedate = 2012-10-06| deadurl=no}} That year he returned to Texas A&M as an associate dean of engineering, engineering research coordinator and associate director of the Texas Engineering Experiment Station. He became acting president for seven months after the death of [[Earl Rudder]] in 1970. He then served as executive vice president for six years. A science building on the campus was named in his honor in 1994.{{cite news |title=Ex-A&M President Luedecke dead at 87 /Retired general also served as AEC chief |date=12 August 1998 |newspaper=Houston Chronicle |location=Section A, Page 23, 3 STAR Edition |url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1998_3075504/ex-a-amp-m-president-luedecke-dead-at-87-retired-g.html |accessdate=21 August 2011 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121022001212/http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1998_3075504/ex-a-amp-m-president-luedecke-dead-at-87-retired-g.html | archivedate = 2012-10-22| deadurl=yes}} He died in [[San Antonio, Texas]], on 8 August 1998 and was buried at [[Fort Sam Houston National Cemetery]] in San Antonio. He was survived by his wife Isabelle, son, Alvin R. Luedecke Jr., daughters Jan Lee Maynard and Miriam Luedecke, and six sisters. His papers are in the Cushing Library at Texas A&M.{{cite web |title=Military History - Cushing Library |url=http://cushing.library.tamu.edu/temp/collections/oral-history-collection/agricultural-history/military-history |accessdate=30 March 2012 |publisher=Texas A&M| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120302084805/http://cushing.library.tamu.edu/temp/collections/oral-history-collection/agricultural-history/military-history | archivedate = 2012-03-02| deadurl=yes}} ==Notes== {{Portal|Biography|World War II|United States Air Force|Nuclear technology}} {{reflist|30em}} ==References== {{refbegin}} * {{cite book | last = Ancell | first = R.
